occurrences.line_text: And with great griefe were often heard to grone,
Which when that Champion heard, with percing point
Ay wont to laugh, when them I heard to cry,
Till I that treachours art haue heard and tride;
With that they heard a roaring hideous sound,
He lowdly brayd, that like was neuer heard,
Whiles they his pittifull aduentures heard,
Heard sound through all the Pallace pleasantly,
Who euer heard of th'Indian Peru?
Which when she heard, as in despightfull wise,
When she her Squire heard speake, she gan appease
But when he heard him speake, streight way he knew
They heard a ruefull voice, that dearnly cride
Which when that warriour heard, dismounting straict
Whom when I heard to beene so ill bestad,
The goddesse heard, and suddeine where she sate,
To magnifie his owne. But when they heard,
He lately heard that dying Lady grone,
At last they heard a horne, that shrilled cleare
Eft through the thicke they heard one rudely rush;
When first I heard her horne sound with such ghastlinesse.
Which was the cause, when earst that horne I heard,
Which when I heard, with horrible affright
That when the varlet heard and saw, streight way
Which when farre off Cymochles heard, and saw,
Which when as Archimago heard, his griefe
He heard a voice, that called loud and cleare,
Againe he heard a more efforced voyce,
Which when he heard, and saw the tokens trew,
Which when the Romanes heard, they hither sent
When as their Captaine heard, in haste he yode,
An hideous roaring farre away they heard,
And as they went, they heard a ruefull cry
Ere long they heard an hideous bellowing
Etfsoones they heard a most melodious sound,
Saue in this Paradise, be heard elswhere:
There, whence that Musick seemed heard to bee,
The constant paire heard all, that he did say,
And heauy tydings heard, whereas she playd
She sweetly heard complaine, both how and what
And tell me, if that ye my sonne haue heard,
Like as an Hynd forth singled from the heard,
And hath the charge of Neptunes mightie heard;
Who when those pittifull outcries he heard,
And with his staffe, that driues his Heard astray,
Which words when Paridell had heard, his hew
Whenas the noble Britomart heard tell
She heard, that she was lineally extract:
Who had forgot, that whilome I heard tell
Except Cleopolis: so heard I say
They heard a noyse of many bagpipes shrill,
So home he marcht emongst the horned heard,
That none of all the Satyres him espyde or heard.
Nine times he heard him come aloft ere day,
But all in vaine: and then turnd to the heard,
Still as she stood, she heard with grieuous throb
Which when she heard, and saw the ghastly fit,
She heard a shrilling Trompet sound aloud,
In full straunge notes was sweetly heard to sound,
Or clashing heard, he fast away did fly,
Soone as he heard, himself he reared light from ground.
Als as she double spake, so heard she double,
So stood Sir Scudamour, when this he heard,
Of outrage for the words, which she heard say,
The wicked weapon heard his wrathfull vow,
All suddenly they heard a troublous noyes,
Of all the heard, meete with so hideous maine,
Into an heard, farre from the husband farme,
Whereto approaching nigh, they heard the sound
When Scudamour heard mention of that speare,
Soone as she heard the name of Artegall,
When Scudamour those heauie tydings heard,
When suddenly behind her backe she heard
That Britomart heard not the shrilling sound,
With that she heard some one close by her side
When he it heard, and how the ground he kist,
Him seemed oft he heard his owne right name.
When so he heard her say, eftsoones he brake
The noble Prince, who neuer heard one word
Which Ladies loue I heard had neuer wonne
Then was there heard a most celestiall sound,
He heard the lamentable voice of one,
All which complaint when Marinell had heard,
Whom hauing lost (as ye haue heard whyleare)
That his false Ladie, as ye heard afore.
I heard report that farre abrode did fly,
Which when as Radigund there comming heard,
In sort as ye haue heard the same of late.
Heard to the end, she was right sore bestad,
She heard a wondrous noise below the hall.
It was not long, before she heard the sound
All which when he vnto the end had heard,
All which when she vnto the end had heard,
Which when the other heard, she sternly frownd
Whom when they heard so say, they lookt about,
But they now hauing throughly heard, and seene
Which when those knights had heard, their harts gan earne,
Mongst which as then, there was for to be heard
All which when as the Prince had heard and seene,
When they had seene and heard her doome a rights
Yet sith he heard but one, that did appeare,
Which when the Prince heard tell, his heart gan earne
That all the people there without it heard,
Which message when Grantorto heard, full fayne
But if she heard of ill, that any did,
Or doen she heard, she would streightwayes inuent,
And if that any ill she heard of any,
Thus whiles they spake, they heard a ruefull shrieke
All which when well Sir Calidore had heard,
Came to the place, whereas ye heard afore
At length he heard vnder the forrests syde
Which when he heard, he inly touched was
The fauour of Belphebe, (as ye heard)
When as vnwares he in the forrest heard
Which when as Cupid heard, he wexed wroth,
All which when Cupid heard, he by and by
Of faire Serena, who as earst you heard,
Ne was there heard, ne was there shepheards swayne
Of a shrill pipe he playing heard on hight,
Knowing his voice although not heard long sin,
Like as a Lion mongst an heard of dere,
The heardes out of their foldes were loosed quight,
Whereas the Heardes were keeping of their neat,
That they were poore heardgroomes, the which whylere
And all their goodly heards did gather round,
To th'heards, but meant them to the damzels fantazy.
The which for want of heards themselues then kept.
Vnwont with heards to watch, or pasture sheepe,
The which to heare, vouchsafe, O dearest dred a-while.
Ioying to heare the birdes sweete harmony,
And homebred euill ye desire to heare,
Then his dull eares, to heare what she did tell;
Least to you hap, that happened to me heare,
She could not heare, nor speake, nor vnderstand;
For anguish great they gan to rend their heare,
And cry, and curse, and raile, and rend her heare,
Vntill the witches speech she gan to heare,
If old Aveugles sonnes so euill heare?
That none can breath, nor see, nor heare at will,
Whiles thus I heare you of your sorrowes treat.
Then heare the storie sad, which I shall tell you briefe.
And well could rule: now he hath left you heare,
O heare, how piteous he to you for ayd does call.
That hardest heart would bleede, to heare their piteous mone.
Ne liuing man like words did euer heare,
But God you neuer let his charmed speeches heare.
And heare the wisedome of her words diuine.
That wonder was to heare her goodly speach:
Her guiltlesse garments, and her golden heare,
The watchman wayting tydings glad to heare,
So shaked he, that horrour was to heare,
Suffice it heare by signes to vnderstand
Of other worldes he happily should heare?
The good Sir Guyon gratiously to heare,
In which he hath great glorie wonne, as I heare tell.
Heare then, ï¿½ man, the sorrowes that vneath
With which he cut a locke of all their heare,
And to her iust conditions of faire peace to heare.
Resort, to heare of straunge aduentures to be told.
Each trembling leafe, and whistling wind they heare,
She list not heare, but her disports poursewd,
That all the forrest quakes to heare him rore:
That seruice well. Her yellow golden heare
At last quite rauisht with delight, to heare
Like did he neuer heare, like did he neuer see.
A daintie damzell, dressing of her heare,
And let him heare some part of their rare melody.
Such seemed they, and so their yellow heare
Right hard it was, for wight, which did it heare,
And on his tender lips the downy heare
That wonder was to heare their trim consort.
To heare her Loue so highly magnifide,
Should of his dearest daughters hard misfortune heare.
And brasen Caudrons thou shalt rombling heare,
Th'old woman wox half blanck, those words to heare;
To heare so often, in that royall hous,
And boastfull men so oft abasht to heare?
To heare the warlike feates, which Homere spake
And wondrous ruth to all, that shall it heare.
Ladies and Lords she euery where mote heare
Into misfortune fell, as ye did heare,
Each shade she saw, and each noyse she did heare,
For her depart, that euer man did heare;
His rugged flesh, and rent his ragged heare:
To heare him threaten so despightfully.
To turne your course, I would to heare desyre,
Vouchsafe with mild regard a wretches cace to heare.
And therefore prayd her wake, to heare him plaine.
What monstrous enmity prouoke we heare,
The God himselfe rending his golden heare,
In signe of silence, as to heare a play,
And from her head oft rent her snarled heare:
She much was cheard to heare him mentiond,
Which that she may the better deigne to heare,
Which when as Scudamour did heare, his heart
Of flashing fire, and heare the ordenance thonder,
Content to heare him speake, and glad to rest withall.
The which mote haue enriched all vs heare.
With rugged beard, and hoarie shagged heare,
Like to the Northren winde, that none could heare:
And round about the same, her yellow heare
Desiring of his Amoret to heare
But no where could her find, nor tydings of her heare.
With needelesse dread, till certaintie ye heare:
That pittie is to heare the perils, which she tride.
The hideous noise of their huge strokes did heare,
Seeking aduentures, where he mote heare tell;
Though there were none her hatefull words to heare:
And sigh full sore, to heare the miserie,
That none might heare the sorrow of my hart,
And count my cares, when none is nigh to heare,
Oft listening if he mote her heare againe;
So he her told: but soone as she did heare
But of her health when Artegall did heare,
All which when Artegall did see, and heare,
And turn'd aside for shame to heare, what he did tell.
To heare the piteous beast pleading her plaintiffe cause.
Yet loth she was, since she no ill did heare,
Or ought to heare, that mote delightfull bee;
As glad to heare of armes, the which now she
Which spitefull words she sore engrieu'd to heare,
Vntill they both doe heare, what she to them will say.
They heare him not, they haue forgot his lore,
Crying to them in vaine, that nould his crying heare.
The gentle knights reioyced much to heare
Where they mote heare the matter throughly scand
Though plaine she saw by all, that she did heare,
Hastily bent, that enterprise to heare,
Did quake to heare, and nigh asunder brast.
Did much abash Sir Artegall to heare,
Sith no redemption nigh she did nor heare nor see.
That her mis-shape much helpt; and her foule heare
And if she hapt of any good to heare,
To heare these tidings, which of none afore
A shamefull vse as euer I did heare,
Hayling that mayden by the yellow heare,
In dread of death, his heasts did gladly heare,
But more enforst my paine, the more my plaints to heare.
Is this the hope that to my hoary heare
And heare th'aduenture of her late mischaunce;
The dastard, that did heare him selfe defyde,
To take the ayre, and heare the thrushes song,
Whom pitying to heare so sore complaine,
So lewdly had abusde, as ye did lately heare.
To erect this wicked custome, which I heare,
Were glad to heare of that aduenture new,
Where none is nigh to heare, that will her rew,
Which to thee flocke, to heare thy louely layes;
And who sees not, would be affrayd to heare:
He sought the plaines; but could no tydings heare.
Whose like he neuer once did speake, nor heare,
And all the while salt teares bedeawd the hearers cheaks.
But he enrag'd with rancor, nothing heares.
To be vnarmd, and curld vncombed heares
In breaded tramels, that no looser heares
His snowy front curled with golden heares,
Staring with hollow eyes, and stiffe vpstanding heares.
The Whistler shrill, that who so heares, doth dy,
Where so he heares, that any doth confound
Prince Arthur heares of Florimell:
So strong is passion, that no reason heares.
What stony hart, that heares thy haplesse fate,
Tell what thou saw'st, maulgre who so it heares.
And knocke his head, and rend his rugged heares,
Will yeeld, but when my piteous plaints he heares,
Into some pit, where she him heares complaine,
Artegall heares of Florimell,
For many scarres and many hoary heares,
That who so heares her heauinesse, would rew
His hearie beames, and flaming lockes dispred,
Which hearing his rash Syre, began to rend
The Sarazin this hearing, rose amain,
By hearing her, and by her sisters lore,
His owne deare Vna hearing euermore
But sober Guyon, hearing him so raile,
The second Bulwarke was the Hearing sence,
Which Guyon hearing, streight his Palmer bad,
To flame the gates, and hearing them to call
The wretched man hearing her call for ayd,
Hearing him those same bloudy lines reherse;
Vnto his caue farre from all peoples hearing,
Is farre from hearing of my heauy plight;
Which Artegall well hearing, though no more
And hearing pleas of people meane and base.
To th'hearing of that former cause in hand,
In th'hearing of full many Knights and Ladies gent.
But Talus hearing her so lewdly raile,
And hearing th'answeres of his pregnant wit,
The Ladie hearing his so courteous speach,
Who hearing how his people badly sped,
Which Coridon first hearing, ran in hast
That she may hearke to loue, and reade this lesson often.
List not to hearke, but made this faire denyall;
Then hearke ye gentle knights and Ladies free,
So well that Leach did hearke to her request,
Yet nould she hearke, ne let him once respyre,
To hearke what any one did good report,
And hearken to the sober speaches, which she spoke.
They to him hearken, as beseemeth meete,
For ill it were to hearken to her cry;
And soone compeld to hearken vnto peace:
But hearken to his lore, and all his counsell hyde.
So litle did they hearken to her sweet beheast.
Did gladly hearken to his graue beheast,
He hearkned, and did stay from further harmes,
He hearkned to his reason, and the childe
Him hearkned to, and soone her selfe arayd,
Soone hearkned, and her painted bote streightway
He hearkned, and his armes about him tooke,
Ne creature saw, but hearkned now and then
Her wisedome did admire, and hearkned to her loring.
The Prince soone hearkned, and his life forgaue.
The Infant hearkned wisely to her tale,
Who hearkning to that voice, him selfe vpreard,
To whose wise read she hearkning, sent me streight
The Ladie hearkning to his sensefull speach,
Saue as thou seest or hearst. But well I wote,
Seemed in heart some hidden care she had,
He could not rest, but did his stout heart eat,
And hope to winne his Ladies heart that day,
Did much emmoue his stout heroï¿½icke heart,
Feele my heart perst with so great agonie,
His heart too high through his great riches store;
But her deare heart with anguish did torment,
Some secret sorrow did her heart distraine:
Can heart, so plung'd in sea of sorrowes deepe,
And in my heart his yron arrow steepe,
Which loue and fortune in her heart had wrought,
That stoutest heart, I weene, could cause to quake.
That hardest heart would bleede, to heare their piteous mone.
Deepe written in my heart with yron pen,
His heart did seeme to melt in pleasures manifold.
That seemd her tender heart was rent in twaine,
The bitter pangs, that doth your heart infest.
In that knights heart, and wordes with bitter teares did steepe.
Whereby close fire into his heart does creepe:
That noble heart as great dishonour doth despize.
And yield your heart, whence ye cannot remoue?
But thine my Deare (welfare thy heart my deare)
A dolefull heart with so disdainfull pride;
Her heart nigh broken was with weary toyle,
For her faint heart was with the frozen cold
In th'heart of euery honourable Dame,
Yet thousand charmes could not her stedfast heart remoue.
Sprinckle her heart, and haughtie courage soften,
My softened heart so sorely doth constraine,
Through cruell knife that her deare heart did kerue.
Albee in heart he like affection fond,
He little answer'd, but in manly heart
Which when as Scudamour did heare, his heart
Trembling in heart, and looking pale and wan,
And heauy heart with comfort doth reioyce.
That so to see him made her heart to quaile:
His mighty heart did almost rend in tway,
In royall heart disdaining to be thrall.
When first he loued her with heart entire,
To hide th'intent, which in my heart did lurke,
Her noble heart with sight thereof was fild
Whose tender heart the faire Belphebe had,
Who seeing his sad plight, her tender heart
Shap'd like a heart, yet bleeding of the wound,
Her tender heart, and made refraine from meat,
His mighty heart with indignation sweld,
My heart was launcht, and learned to haue loued,
Which when I red, my heart did inly earne,
Vnto the passion, that her heart opprest,
His stubborne heart, that neuer felt misfare
Thus whilst his stony heart with tender ruth
Then gan her heart to faint, and quake, and earne,
Which of the Nymphes his heart so sore did mieue.
His cleared heart eftsoones away gan chace
And with full heauy heart with them he far'd,
Her heart for rage did grate, and teeth did grin:
Out of his breast the very heart haue rended:
How euer it his noble heart did gall,
There looking forth, shee in her heart did find
Whereat her heart was fild with hope and drede;
The felnesse of her heart, right fully bent
Restlesse, recomfortlesse, with heart deepe grieued,
Into her eye, which th'heart mote haue relieued,
My heart at first betrayd, will ye betray
Now ye haue made my heart to wake alway,
Or that some pensiuenesse to heart she tooke.
Of slaughtred carkasses, her heart did quake
Her heart gan grudge, for very deepe despight
He much admired both his heart and hew,
Suffring my hand against my heart to stray:
Which when the Prince heard tell, his heart gan earne
His heart gan faint, and streight he tooke his flight
That yron heart it hardly could sustaine:
His heart with vengeaunce inwardly did swell,
To Calepine, his heart did inly flame
His gentle heart with indignation sweld,
That, were no might in man, nor heart in Knights,
Her heart does quake, and deadly pallid hew
With grace from her, whose loue his heart hath sore engrieued.
And liking in her yet vntamed heart procure.
His Loues deare spoile, in which his heart was prayde,
The gentle heart scornes base disparagement.
At sight whereof his barbarous heart was fired,
But Radigund full of heart-gnawing griefe,
Was at his backe with heartlesse heedinesse,
Drawne with the powre of an heart-robbing eye,
But ioyd weake wemens hearts to tempt, and proue
With lighter hearts vnto their home retird;
Ne in their frosen hearts feele kindly flame:
And all mens eyes and hearts, which there among
For that had might to change the hearts of men
Then suddenly as if their hearts did faile,
And hearts quite robbed with so glorious sight,
The hearts of some, that fairest her did weene;
That could haue perst the hearts of Tigres & of Beares.
Yet neither shewed to other their hearts priuity.
For oftentimes faint hearts at first espiall
And valiant hearts, in thoughts lesse hard and bold,
The eares and hearts of all that goodly crew,
Each one did flie; their hearts began to faile,
That from thy tongue thy hearts intent doth hold.
The skill whereof to Princes hearts he doth reueale.
Their hardned hearts, enur'd to bloud and cruelty.
Made kill her selfe for very hearts despight,
And gracious speach, did steale mens hearts away.
With hearts dismay and inward dolour queld,
Their hearts were sicke, their sides were sore, their feete were
And th'hearts of men, as your eternall dowre,
That could so meekly make proud hearts auale,
Wrapped in wretched cares and hearts vnrest,
With heary glib deform'd, and meiger face,
His dreadfull heast, much lesse him match in fight,
And him forbidden, who his heast obserued.
Regarding nought religion, nor their holy heast.
And she that hight of many heastes Polynome,
The sacred things, and holy heasts foretaught.
T'obay the heasts of mans well ruling hand,
In dread of death, his heasts did gladly heare,
As if he long had to his heasts bene trayned.
But hasty heat tempring with sufferance wise,
From the fierce heat, and rest their weary limbs a tide.
For though a tree I seeme, yet cold and heat me paines.
One pricking towards them with hastie heat,
For other clothes he could not weare for heat,
To kindle heat of corage priuily:
The knight was fiers, and full of youthly heat:
And turning wrathfull fire to lustfull heat,
Which shielded them against the boyling heat,
This Nymph, quite tyr'd with heat of scorching ayre,
Then first the coale of kindly heat appeares
Of looser life, and heat of hardiment,
With heat, toyle, wounds, armes, smart, & inward fire
Did heale his wounds, and scorching heat alay,
Did rend the ratling skyes with flames of fouldring heat.
And was yclad, for heat of scorching aire,
And with my heat kindled his cruell fyre;
But Guyon, in the heat of all his strife,
Therein did often quench his thristy heat,
Appease his heat, or hastie passage stay;
The hastie heat of his auowd reuenge delayd.
Who maistring them, renewd his former heat;
In which she often vsd from open heat
The rash reuengers heat. Words well dispost
And settle patience in so furious heat?
So hasty heat soone cooled to subdew:
But to delay the heat, least by mischaunce
It now deuoures with flames and scorching heat,
Nor scorching heat, nor cold intemperate
As faint through heat, or dight to pleasant sin,
So when they slaked had the feruent heat
She bath'd her brest, the boyling heat t'allay;
Others lay shaded from the scorching heat;
After her heat the breathing cold to taste;
And kindled heat, that soone in flame forth brust:
From scorching heat her daintie limbes to shade:
What time the dayes with scorching heat abound,
Till th'heat of his fierce furie he had spent:
Like as in sommers day when raging heat
So huge his hammer and so fierce his heat,
So furiously she strooke in her first heat,
At length when as he saw her hastie heat
As blasted bloosme through heat doth languish & decay;
And hard to finde, that heat of youthfull spright
Did mollifie, and calme her raging heat.
Mongst which the cause of their so cruell heat
Rose vp, inspired with heroicke heat,
Her snowy substance melted as with heat,
Soone as he feeles it mollifide with heat,
Nathlesse when calmed was her furious heat,
With his sharpe wheeles, in his first rages heat,
Like a fell mastiffe through enraging heat,
As doth a Steare, in heat of sommers day,
And hauing somewhat calm'd his wrathfull heat
Layes of sweete loue and youthes delightfull heat:
Offred him drinke, to quench his thirstie heat,
Like lyfull heat to nummed senses brought,
The heate whereof, and harmefull pestilence
With heate and humour, breedes the liuing wight.
Through toylesome heate and labour of her weary fight.
With such faire words she did their heate asswage,
Like to a flowre, that feeles no heate of sunne,
Whose harmefull head, thrice heated in the fire,
What heauens? what altars? what enraged heates
